subject: Re: [junit] setUp versus constructors
msgSnippet: ... I find that setUp() reveals intent pretty well. Some people have difficulty with the idea of storing fixture objects in fields, as they incorrectly think
messageBody:
clgonsal wrote:
>
>
> I've been using JUnit for a few years now, and one thing that's always
> bothered me is the "setUp" method.
>
> I always do my initialization in my constructor (if I'm not just doing
> it at the field definition) as constructors allow me to initialize
> final fields. The semantics of using a constructor also seem far more
> obvious to me as everyone reading my code knows Java, while not
> everyone is a JUnit guru.
>
> The additional complexity of having the (as far as I can tell)
> redundant setUp method seems counterproductive, so why does setUp exist?

I find that "setUp()" reveals intent pretty well. Some people have
difficulty with the idea of storing fixture objects in fields, as they
incorrectly think that they can write to those fields from one test and
read those values from the next test. For this reason, I find that when
I explain how to refactor code out of tests into the setUp() method,
people understand the concepts more easily.

It's also worth noting that in NUnit, for example, test case instances
are pooled, so initializing in the constructor does not behave as you
might expect. There's nothing in the contract of the JUnit test case
that guarantees that instances are not pooled, so JUnit 5.0, for
example, could decide to pool instances of test case. At that point,
you'd have to change your code.

I hope that sheds some light on the matter.
